alt_statements.statement: I don’t like the idea of big coastal cities deciding everything, but I also don’t think the current Electoral College works perfectly. I’d support reforms like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or proportionally in each state, so rural and working-class folks like me still matter, but elections better reflect the actual vote. That keeps a buffer against pure majority rule while cutting down on situations where the popular vote and the presidency don’t match.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count equally no matter what state they live in. It feels wrong that someone can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and it discourages people in “safe” states from even bothering to participate. A popular vote system would push candidates to talk to more diverse communities instead of just battleground states, which lines up more with my values of fairness and inclusion.

As a retired artist and lifelong Californian, I’ve always believed that every person’s voice should count equally, and our presidential elections should reflect that. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, or at least substantially reformed so that votes in big blue states like mine aren’t effectively taken for granted while smaller swing states get all the attention. To me, a more direct and democratic system would better honor the dignity and equality of each voter, which fits both my liberal values and my Catholic belief in the fundamental worth of every person.

Given how divided the country feels lately, I think we need reforms that make people feel their vote truly counts, no matter where they live. I’d support changes like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electoral votes so the final result better reflects the will of the majority, while still encouraging candidates to pay attention to smaller and rural states. That seems like a fairer balance between honoring our constitutional traditions and updating the system for today’s population and politics.

As someone who believes in both personal freedom and fairness, I think the Electoral College needs significant reform, if not replacement. I’d support a system like the National Popular Vote interstate compact or ranked-choice voting for president, so every vote counts equally no matter what state you live in. That feels more just and would encourage candidates to listen to people across the whole country, not just in a few swing states.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot truly counts the same, no matter what state they live in. As someone who cares a lot about fairness and comes from a Hispanic family in California, it doesn’t feel right that some states get more attention and power while others are basically ignored. A popular vote system would push candidates to listen to all communities, including younger people and minorities, instead of just focusing on swing states.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose by making sure smaller and rural states like mine in Oregon aren’t completely drowned out by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d support reforms that keep the basic system but make it fairer, like adopting the Maine and Nebraska model everywhere so electoral votes are split by congressional district instead of winner-take-all.

Given how much emphasis we put on fairness and representation in civics class, the Electoral College feels outdated and undemocratic to me. I think we should move to a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, whether they live in Connecticut or a swing state, and so candidates have to care about all communities, including racially diverse and younger voters like me. If a full popular vote isn’t possible right away, at least states should adopt a proportional system so the outcome better reflects the actual will of the people.

I get that the Electoral College was meant to balance out big and small states, but it feels outdated now and doesn’t really match how people actually vote. I’d rather see a system where the popular vote decides the winner, maybe with some safeguards like ranked-choice voting so third-party votes aren’t “wasted.” Living in Colorado, it sometimes feels like our votes matter less than in a few swing states, and that doesn’t seem fair.

I don’t really understand all the big rules about voting yet, but I think everyone’s vote should count the same, no matter what state they live in. I think the Electoral College should be kept, but modernized a bit to reflect how the country has changed. As a naturalized citizen, I respect the Electoral College because it forces candidates to appeal to a broad range of states, not just the biggest cities, and that protects voices in smaller or less-populated places like where many immigrant families build their lives. As someone who believes in evidence-based systems and fairness, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in, maybe by using a national popular vote. As a Democrat and a believer in one-person-one-vote, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every American’s ballot counts equally, whether you live in Ohio like me or in a so‑called “swing state.” It doesn’t make sense that a candidate can win the popular vote and still lose the presidency, and that system leaves a lot of people feeling ignored and stressed about whether their voice matters. I think the Electoral College should be changed so that everyone’s vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in. As someone who believes in individual voices mattering equally, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, no matter what state you live in. As a Democrat and a working artist, I want a system that actually reflects the will of the people, not one that can hand victory to someone who loses the popular vote.

I think the Electoral College should mostly be kept as it is, because it helps make sure smaller and less populated states like mine still have a real voice and aren’t drowned out by big cities on the coasts. I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose by making sure smaller states and less populated areas like a lot of the country I work in actually matter, instead of everything being decided by a few big cities. At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to feel that every vote should count as equally as possible, no matter where you live. As a pilot, I spend my life relying on clear procedures and systems that are constantly reviewed and updated when they no longer serve safety or fairness, and I think our Electoral College needs that same kind of overhaul. I’d like to see us move toward a national popular vote—possibly with ranked-choice voting—so every vote counts equally regardless of state, and candidates have to appeal to the whole country, not just a few battlegrounds.

I don’t see a good reason to scrap the Electoral College. This country’s supposed to be a union of states, not just a few big cities calling all the shots, and the Electoral College helps keep that balance so folks in places like small towns and working-class communities still matter. If anything, I’d support reforms that keep the system but make it harder for shady backroom deals or last-minute legal tricks to overturn clear results.

I think the Electoral College still has an important role in protecting the voice of smaller states like Missouri, so I wouldn’t support scrapping it altogether. However, I’d be open to some sensible reforms—like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules around faithless electors—so that people feel their votes matter more without turning our elections into a chaotic national popular vote contest.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you’re in New York, Texas, or a small town anywhere else. The current Electoral College gives too much power to a few swing states and can ignore the will of the majority, which doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness and democracy. As a Democrat and a Catholic who cares about everyone having a voice, I want a system where candidates have to speak to all communities—including Hispanic and working-class families like mine—not just the ones that tip the Electoral College.

At my age, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I’ve come to think the Electoral College just doesn’t reflect the will of the people the way it should. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least adopt reforms like proportional allocation of electors, so every vote counts the same whether you’re in Mississippi or California. That kind of change would strengthen our democracy, encourage candidates to care about all communities—rural, urban, and everything in between—and fit better with my belief in both personal freedom and a fair, sustainable future for everyone.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the voice of smaller and less populated states so that our elections aren’t decided only by a handful of big cities. If anything, reforms should focus on improving transparency and security in how states run their elections and allocate their electors, not on replacing the system altogether.

At my age, I’ve come to respect the wisdom of the Founders, and I believe the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states and preventing a few big cities from dominating national elections. That said, I would support modest reforms that increase transparency and ensure states run their elections cleanly and consistently, perhaps by standardizing some procedures. I’m wary of rushing into a national popular vote, which I fear could deepen divisions and invite even more chaos and legal battles. Instead, we should focus on tightening election integrity and improving civic education so people better understand why the system exists in the first place.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts the same no matter what state they live in. It feels wrong that someone can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and as a Democrat and a liberal, I care a lot about making our system more directly democratic. If a full popular vote isn’t possible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to move us closer to one-person, one-vote in practice.

I’d scrap the Electoral College and go with a straightforward popular vote, maybe with ranked-choice so people can vote third party without “wasting” their ballot. As a small business owner who busts his ass every day, I don’t see why my vote should count differently just because of what state I’m in—one person, one vote seems like the most honest, liberty-respecting way to do it.

As someone who deeply believes in equal opportunities and one person, one vote, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. A popular vote system would encourage candidates to speak to all Americans, not just swing-state voters, and better reflect the will of the people while still respecting our constitutional framework through a carefully designed reform or amendment.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every vote from every person counts the same, no matter what state they live in. At my age, I’ve lived through enough elections to see that the Electoral College, while imperfect, serves an important purpose in balancing the influence of large and small states. As a conservative and a veteran, I think the Electoral College should be preserved because it forces candidates to pay attention to a broad range of states, not just the biggest cities and population centers. That said, I’d support reforms that increase transparency and standardize election procedures across states, as long as they don’t undermine the balance between large and small states.

As a Democrat and someone who works with complex systems for a living, the Electoral College feels like an outdated mechanism that distorts the will of voters and overweights a handful of swing states. I’d like to see it replaced with a national popular vote, ideally with reforms like ranked-choice voting so every ballot matters equally and candidates have to appeal to a broader, more diverse electorate.

I think we should get rid of the Electoral College and move to a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts the same no matter what state they’re in. At 88, I’ve watched too many elections where the candidates only seem to care about a handful of “swing states,” and that leaves rural communities like mine and our environmental concerns on the sidelines.
